en: Loading screen texts and titles
Graveyard Shift
Ghost Town was destroyed. The Undertaker had to leave and find a way to lift the curse that doomed those around him.
The Undertaker returned from a funeral to discover his hometown ravaged by a violent cult.
The Undertaker asked Harrington to help him end his miserable existence.

The Undertaker and Harrington arrived at the Mad King's hideout.
They were looking for Reverend Ashmore.

In his quest to lift the curse, the Undertaker headed to the Demon Prince's swamp hideout.
He and Harrington lay in wait until dawn, prepared to end the cult once and for all.
Objective text
Time of day:
Have Harrington kill Morin
Kill the Demon Prince
Prevent the Demon Prince from cursing the altars
All altars have been cursed by the Demon Prince
Don't allow any altars to be cursed (Optional)
Kill all henchmen in the hideout
Kill all bandits
Kill the cultists
Kill all cultists
Free Oswald Harrington
Do not trigger the alarm until Oswald is free (Optional)
Find Reverend Ashmore
Subdue the "Mad King" to learn about Ashmore's whereabouts
Free Reverend Ashmore
Loot the supply boxes for food
Run away with Reverend Ashmore
Wait 2 days before returning to the Hermit
Pay another visit to the Hermit
Learn about Reverend Ashmore in the Opium Den
Find Reverend Ashmore west of the Railroad Station
Pay a visit to Red Coyote
Learn more about the Old Seamstress
Bring 10 ginseng roots to Red Coyote
Kill the bear with a broken skull, somewhere in the Mountains
Return to Red Coyote
Go to Ghost Town and dig up the body from the main square
Return to the Old Seamstress
When you are ready to end your misery, return to the Hermit and accept your death
Destroy the blood vials
Use the altar to damage it
...OR Kill all cultists
Kill the Demon Prince
Go to the Hermit's Hut
Buy at least 12 Tobacco Bags at the Tobacco Plantation
Sell the tobacco in Town
Go to the saloon in Town and hire a gunman
Return to Ghost Town and retrieve Harrington's food
Return to Ghost Town and end your life
Go to the Cultist Hideout in the morning and attack them
Dawn
Morning
Midday
Afternoon
Dusk
Winds of Time
The day consists of 4 parts: Dawn, Morning, Midday and Afternoon. You can explore one location during each part of the day. Travelling to a new location will change the time of day.
Hard Times

You need to eat every day.
A character needs 1 food portion to remain healthy. 2 portions will make him more energetic.

If a character skips a meal, he will be hungry. Denying him food on the second and following days will cause them to become very weak.
Starved characters require 2 food portions to restore their strength.
Camp
The day is nearing its end and you set up camp. It is time to distribute the meals. You have
Food Portions. Who eats?
The day is nearing its end and you set up camp. It is time to distribute the meals. Unfortunately, you have no more food.
is already full.
is satiated.
is hungry.
is starving!
This member of the posse doesn't need more food.
Get some sleep
A new sun
Another day had arrived. No rest for the wicked.
Exploration prompts
Falltown

The town was a loose collection of decrepit plank houses.
Falltown locals were a rare and sorrowful sight.
The Undertaker went to the saloon.
The Undertaker went to the market.
Black Magic Saloon
Most of the tables were occupied by card players. The whiskey bar hosted a group of guns for hire.
The Undertaker hired a gunman.
All the local scoundrels, bandits and lunatics hung out in the Saloon. It was the ideal place to look for a new posse member.
The Undertaker's posse was already full, however.
The Undertaker hired Fleischer - a tough fighter, but a weak shot ([%0])
The Undertaker hired Johnson - a fast but fragile fighter ([%0])
The Undertaker fired Fleischer.
The Undertaker fired Johnson.

Fleischer was a well-known bounty hunter with a gold bullet where a tooth once had been.

The bullet in his jaw was the only one that ever came close to killing him.

Johnson was a sad man who remembered slavery all too well.
During these turbulent times, life had forced him to train his reflexes, while luck had allowed him to survive.
Fleischer muttered that he would wait here for another job, but he didn't seem too happy about it.
Johnson was visibly disappointed, but didn't say anything. He just frowned and went back to his table in the corner.
Fleischer returned the money. He refused to travel with Johnson. He didn't give a reason.
Johnson returned the money. He said he'd never work with a former slaver like Fleischer.
The Undertaker didn't have that much.
The Undertaker decided to hire him.
Another gunman joined the Undertaker's posse.

Unfortunately, no one at the saloon wanted to accompany the Undertaker.
It seems only cowards remained at the Black Magic.
The Market
The first thing that hit the Undertaker's nostrils as he entered the market was the stench of cheap, strong liquor. The market also offered a variety of other low quality goods.
Ma McCarthy's Distillery

The Distillery produced strong whiskey that tasted like a wet dog and burned like poison.
Their motto was "Ma McCarthy's whiskey: a real man can take six shots and keep on firing.".
Tobacco Plantation
The tobacco from Bryan Cole's plantation was famous for its moldy look and intense aroma.
Opium Den

The Opium Den was that rare business which could increase profits while displaying the omnipresent misery of its customers.

The room was filled with beggars, cowboys and foreigners of all kinds.

A Chinese man was dozing off behind a table opposite to the entrance. It could only be Jingle Tommy.
The Undertaker asked Jingle Tommy about Reverend Ashmore.

Jingle Tommy smiled without opening his eyes and spoke in a lilting near-whisper. The Reverend was supposed to arrive in the Railroad Station a few days ago. Jingle Tommy had found something to occupy him while he waited.

Jingle Tommy welcomed Reverend Ashmore with a smile.

They smoked a little and talked about old times. Tommy gave the Undertaker a bag of opium as a reward for his assistance.

Jingle Tommy greeted the Undertaker with a smile.

Reverend Ashmore was there too. He invited them to sit, chat and smoke a little something.

Finally, Tommy presented the posse with a large bag of opium. A "finder's fee" he called it.
Jingle Tommy smiled and thanked the Undertaker one more time before falling into a nodding stupor.
Caravan

The Undertaker visited The Caravan, a loosely-knit group of people who never stayed in one place for long. This was either because they were always looking for new sources of revenue, or because eventually the locals would tire of their scams and inflated prices.

For all their faults, however, they had the best supply of liquor, tobacco and opium within a hundred miles.

The Undertaker visited The Caravan, a loosely-knit group of people who never stayed in one place for long. This was either because they were always looking for new sources of revenue, or because eventually the locals would tire of their scams and inflated prices.

For all their faults, however, they had the best supply of liquor, tobacco and opium within a hundred miles.

To his surprise, he found a family there he had lent money to for their journey along the Oregon Trail. The family had never forgotten his kindness and now repaid it considerably.
Sawmill

The Sawmill was managed by Malcolm Topper, a man of few words and quirky habits.

If you could stomach the unpleasant sounds he made when spitting through his teeth, you could make a deal.
Cultist Hideout

The ranch had flooded a couple of years back and the waters never receded. Swarms of insects buzzed over the murky, corpse-filled waters.

Unnerving noises came from the ranch. Laughter, howls, gunshots and the sound of metal on metal floated across the water, conjuring in the men's minds a fearsome image of gruesome monstrosities.

Harrington suggested an early morning attack would catch their foes off-guard.

The ranch had flooded a couple of years back and the waters never receded. Swarms of insects buzzed over the murky, corpse-filled waters.

The ranch was silent and the morning fog covered the approach route. The posse knew this was the time to strike.
The posse readied themselves for the attack.
The Ranch was accessible from three sides. The Undertaker approached from the...
The Ranch was accessible from three sides. Harrington approached from the...
The Ranch was accessible from three sides. Ashmore approached from the...
The Ranch was accessible from three sides. Fleischer approached from the...
The Ranch was accessible from three sides. Johnson approached from the...
... southwest - through a large clearing.
... southeast - through a ruined farmhouse.
... northwest - where a middle-sized, worn-out house was standing.
The posse reconsidered their plan.
The posse set up camp and waited for the right time.
The city was a cabinet of horrors, the streets strewn with the bloody bodies of townsfolk, killed by the diabolical cult.
The Undertaker buried all the bodies.

It took the Undertaker and Harrington an entire day burying the dead, carrying corpses through the blood-spattered streets.

The Undertaker couldn't shake the notion that all of this was his fault. He told Harrington as much, relating the story of his continued misfortunes, but omitting the Devil's trickery.

Harrington was skeptical of the curse, but suggested that visiting Empus the hermit might help the Undertaker find peace.
Ghost Town

This town had been the Undertaker's shelter from the past, a place where his presence wouldn't hurt anyone close to him.

Still, the curse had followed him here and this once-thriving town was now in ruins.

He turned the main square into a cemetery. It felt like the only proper way to honor the dead.
Oswald took some food from his abandoned house. They were ready to continue their journey.
The Undertaker went to the main square.

The Undertaker used almost all of his resources on the cemetary. He made every coffin, cross and tombstone himself, carving epitaphs for Jari Bergman the singer, the kind-hearted Regina Zak, the old banker Sakamoto, young Nicko and more.
The Undertaker sat down to a grim prayer, determined to communicate with the dead.
The Undertaker returned to the edge of town.

The Undertaker sat among the graves of his dead friends and enemies.

His prayer wasn't religious, more a gloomy reflection on his past and present actions.

The Undertaker got drunk, took a generous portion of medicinal tinctures and built himself a comfortable coffin.
He found the work calming and meditative.
The Undertaker wanted to make an offering.

The Undertaker was consumed with the idea of offering entertainment for those on the other side.

It was hard to say whether it was Undertaker or the spirits that truly desired an offering of
tobacco bags,
liquor and
opium pipes.
Unfortunately, he didn't have those items on him.

The air felt lighter. It seemed the dead were grateful. It would be a joyous night in Ghost Town.

Each member of the posse felt the clear presence of guardian spirits.

The air felt lighter. It seemed the dead were grateful. It would be a joyous night in Ghost Town.

The posse members' weapons glowed faintly with ghastly power.

The air felt lighter. It seemed the dead were grateful. It would be a joyous night in Ghost Town.

Every member of the posse felt particularly agile that night.
The Undertaker prayed for a blessing of protection.
The Undertaker prayed for a blessing of precision.
The Undertaker prayed for a blessing of speed.
But what did the Undertaker expect in return? The power of the spirits could affect the posse in a variety of ways.
The spirits fell silent. The Undertaker knew they were now truly free.

The Undertaker felt the grief of Ghost Town dissapate and blow away on the wind.

Shortly thereafter a new, sweet fruit began to grow in the fields there. The Undertaker liked to think it was a gift from the liberated spirits.
The Undertaker exhumed one of the bodies to obtain a lock of hair from one of the curse's victims.
The Undertaker prepared to end his own life.

Harrington returned from patrol, reporting increased cultist activity in the area. The Undertaker told him of his decision to end his life and asked for his help.

Reluctantly, Harrington agreed.
Undertaker decided he would not die tonight. He wanted to make sure his companions were ready to fight the cultists.
The posse waited until dusk, determined to honor Undertaker's last wish.

The Undertaker couldn't bring himself to exhume his friends. Instead, he uncovered Bloomberg, a local gambler and perfume aficionado. His body was a foul smelling pile of rot.

With a grimace, the Undertaker retrieved a lock of his hair and re-buried him.
The next step

While the Undertaker dug graves for the cultists, Harrington perused a map he'd found.

A hideout was marked to the south. Apparently it was a ranch that had flooded and now sat in the middle of a swamp.
The search continues

After two days, the Undertaker decided it was time to return to the Hermit.

Surely wise old Empus could come up with something to change his fate.
Light of the dead

In the morning, the Undertaker noticed that one of the candles he saved from the Demon Prince was still lit. In fact it  didn't look to have shrunk one bit. Heartened, his first thought was that this candle had the power to light the way for both the living and the dead. Thinking it might come in handy one day, he pocketed the trinket.
Decaying Post Office

This former federal post office still received messages and documents, but was now a decaying hangout for crooks and outlaws who traded information about the region. Cody Blake Ash supervised the business.
The Undertaker bought the daily price list ([%0])
The Undertaker bought price lists for two days ([%0])
The Undertaker reviewed his daily price list.
The Undertaker reviewed the next day's price list.
Today's price list:
Tomorrow's price list:
TOWN -
CARAVAN -
OPIUM DEN -
TOBACCO PLANTATION -
SAWMILL -
WHISKEY DISTILLERY -
WANDERING SHOP -
"PROTECTION" SHOP -
Kollmann's Gunshop
Maybe not the best guns from Tennessee to California, but the deadliest ones around here.
Hermit's Hut

A thin column of acrid smoke rose from the shabby hut, home of Empus the Hermit.

He greeted the posse with a tired voice, telling them he already knew why they had come.

A thin column of acrid smoke rose from the shabby hut, home of Empus the Hermit.

They found him alone, muttering under his breath to no one.
The Undertaker told the story of his curse and how it had plagued him.

The Hermit remained silent a long time after the Undertaker finished his tale of woe.

Finally, he spoke. The curse was powerful, he said. Empus would not be able to lift it alone. And he needed time to learn more about it. Two days of study should suffice.
The Undertaker told of his unsuccessful expedition.

The Hermit smiled mysteriously, but did not reply.

The Undertaker begged, pleaded, cursed and threatened, but Empus was impenetrable. Resigned, the gravedigger decided to return to Ghost Town and take his own life to avoid causing any more harm.
The Undertaker asked if Empus knew how to lift the curse.

The Hermit turned his milky eyes towards the Undertaker. He mentioned three individuals that could help.

The first was the Old Seamstress, a voodoo priestess who lived somewhere in the swamps.

The second was Red Coyote, an Indian shaman. He was a fretful man, but strong in the traditions of his ancestors.

He lived to the west at the foot of the mountains.

The last but not least was Reverend Ashmore, who no one had seen for some time.

Empus said the Undertaker should seek out Jingle Tommy, the proprietor of the Opium Smoking Room, for more information.
With an unnerving grin, the Hermit smiled and asked whether there was anything else.
Railroad Station

The "Iron Globetrotter" station building was deserted, but a small hut with a mortar and pestle sign stood nearby.
A notice on the wall said Merchant Train called "Protection" was due to arrive in the morning.

The "Iron Globetrotter" station building was deserted, but a small hut with a mortar and pestle sign stood nearby.

As promised by the timetable, an armored Merchant Train called "Protection" waited on the track.
The Undertaker waited for a while.
The Undertaker got on the train.
Protection Merchant Train

Protection was a heavily armored vehicle armed with gatling guns and a contingent of guards. It belonged to the mysterious entrepreneur known as The Protector, and was used as a mobile shop for high-value transactions. Jacobson Price ran sales.
The Undertaker browsed the merchandise.
Secret of the rotten oak

After hours of searching, the posse found the place the old soldier had spoken of, a rotten oak at the base of a hill.

Excited, they looked inside the tree.

There it was. A giant, steel safe, full of treasures plundered during the civil war.

It had a round, rotating, three-step lock. The code consisted of five rotations, each in alternating directions.
The Undertaker attempted to crack the safe.
The Undertaker read the letter.
Keecham, before rebels decide to attack the bank, be sure to change the safe code to 3-2-3-2-
The tumbler was set to
The Undertaker set it to 1.
The Undertaker set it to 2.
The Undertaker set it to 3.
The Undertaker quit.

There was a distinctive click as the safe opened. The soldier had been right, it was full of treasures.

They took it all and left hastily.
The code was wrong.
Dead Man Walking

The posse encountered a wounded man in a torn Civil War uniform. Delirious, he seemed to think he knew the Undertaker and kept calling him "Tomas Marshall".

He spoke of war spoils hidden in "our" safe, assuring the Undertaker that it was secure inside a rotting oak at the base of a hill in the southeast.
He said the clerk who last changed the combination vanished, though rumors said he was hiding in the mountains.

After sharing his story, the man looked relieved, as though he had just relinquished a heavy burden. His breathing became slower as a placid smile stole over his countenance. Ten minutes later he was dead.
Bottoms up

Harrington saw something glittery by the side of the road, his eyes settling on an empty whiskey bottle half-buried in the gravel. Investigation turned up a note inside. The message read:

"Halpin, my dearest companion, this will be my last message. I am leaving this impious land to the rats, snakes and coyotes and travel to the Old World. I won't be another skull on the pile. Should you need assistance in your travels, try the post office southwest of Ghost Town. Good luck, amigo."
A message from the stranger

The posse came across a very peculiar man who walked slowly and clumsily and stank of death.

The man walked straight up to the Undertaker and handed him an envelope.

When asked about the contents, he pointed toward his sewn-shut mouth and walked away.
Undertaker opened the envelope.

A letter in elaborate script read: "I hear you are trying to find me. I am told you are a handsome man, and I fancy the pleasure of your company. Enclosed are directions to my home. It's a swamp, but a cozy one.

- Ellena, the Seamstress".
The Crossroads
The posse came across a solitary woman on her hands and knees in the middle of the crossroads. Exhausted to the point of death, she begged them for food.
The Undertaker shared some food with her ([%0])
The Undertaker refused. His men needed it more.

She noisily devoured the portions, thanking the men between chews. She said her name was Jane and that she was married to Saarijarvi, who used to own the nearby trading post.

They had been attacked by bandits and Saarij√§rvi had been killed. She had been trying to reach the Railroad Station to withdraw their savings and reopen the business. Now she had the strength to finish her journey.

She said if they came to the trading post, she would give them special prices on her wares.

The woman croaked resignedly and collapsed.

When she was dead, the Undertaker buried her on the side of the road, taking the few dollars she had on her in lieu of funeral payment.

The Undertaker was willing to help the woman but the posse didn't have any food. The woman croaked resignedly and collapsed.

When she was dead, the Undertaker buried her on the side of the road, taking the few dollars she had on her in lieu of funeral payment.
The trading post had been completely rebuilt. Jane greeted the posse with a smile, thanked them for saving her life, and offered them a healthy discount on her wares.
Bridge

A one-handed man sat at the entrance to the bridge, wrapped in a poncho. He recognized Harrington, who introduced him to the rest of the posse.

Bloody Bill had been a successful bounty hunter before he'd lost his hand. He and Harrington had some history. He offered to teach the posse what he called a "handy" trick for a fee. It wasn't cheap, even at the discount rate he said he was giving them.
The posse paid Bloody Bill ([%0])
Unfortunately, the posse didn't have enough money.

It took Bill an entire day to teach them the trick.

In the end, only one person was able to grasp the complexity of this strange ability.

The old bounty hunter took to the road a lot richer.
Abandoned Wagon

The group found a damaged wagon.

After investigating, Harrington determined it had come from the west but had been intercepted by people coming from the north. The people then took one person from the wagon and rode back where they came from.

The wagon held several interesting items, but the weather was deteriorating by the minute. A vicious sandstorm looked to be brewing.
Try to collect everything despite the incoming sandstorm.
Grab the immediately available items and run from the sandstorm.

The sandstorm hit while the posse was still collecting loot, scattering them.

It took the posse several hours to get together again.
The posse collected several trinkets, then retreated out of harm's way.
Riverside Lair

The tracks led them to two ruined buildings on a hill overlooking a river. Inhuman laughter and howling emanated from the compound.

Harrington scouted ahead, returning to report that the compound was inhabited by men following the orders of an insane cultist they called the Mad King.
Ashmore was here, though dead or alive was anyone's guess.
The posse approached to infiltrate the compound.
The posse decided this wasn't the right time to strike.

The boat floated with the current, they were out of danger.

Reverend Ashmore thanked everyone and asked why they wanted to find him. When the Undertaker told him about his curse, the priest shook his head in embarassement, replying that he merely had, as all men did, the power to do good. He offered to join the posse and help with the search.
The Undertaker accepted.
The Undertaker declined.

Reverend Ashmore inclined his head with a smile and pointed to the heap of items stocked on the boat. They were almost all his possessions, confiscated by the Mad King's followers.

After rummaging through the collection, he produced a masterfully crafted rifle he called the Bone Hand.

Ashmore presented it to Undertaker, warning that it should only be handled by emissaries of Death. Clearly, he believed that Undertaker was one.

Reverend Ashmore's face became solemn as he gestured to the heap of items stocked on the boat. They were almost all his possessions, confiscated by the Mad King's followers.

After rummaging through the collection, he produced a masterfully crafted rifle he called the Bone Hand.

Ashmore presented it to Undertaker, warning that it should only be handled by emissaries of Death. Clearly, he believed that Undertaker was one.
Indian Tipi

The party arrived in front of an Indian Tipi decorated with large skulls. A burly Indian man covered in scars sat in the middle of the tent, the floor beneath him stained dark red.

Red Coyote neither smiled nor greeted them. It took the posse a few minutes to realize he was blind, despite the intense way he stared at them.
The Undertaker explained that he wanted to change his fate and lift the curse.

Red Coyote cut him off, jumping to his feet and grabbing the gravedigger by the throat. He seemed outraged that they had arrived without "tribute." The posse gathered that they could assuage this tribute by providing ten ginseng roots.
Undertaker gave Red Coyote what he demanded ([%0])

Red Coyote accepted the tribute, but it didn't seem to improve his demeanor.

He snarled something about proving their mettle and hunt for a bear with a broken skull.

The legendary bear skull rolled towards Red Coyote's feet. The shaman nodded slowly and began an eerie chant.

He smeared the blood from his wounds onto the Undertaker, threw some of the red dirt at him and began dancing and chanting.

Finally he fell silent. The shaman assured the Undertaker that his burden should now be eased.

The gravedigger wasn't convinced.
Blue Stone Slope

There had been a landslide here that uncovered seams of unique minerals in the bedrock. Some said there never were blue stones here. Others said looters had depleted the deposit years ago. Dense fog obscured the area.

The Posse's arrival startled a coyote, which ran off with something in its mouth.
The posse ran after the coyote into the fog.
Harrington lured the coyote with their provisions ([%0])

The posse dispersed to search of the coyote.

Eventually Harrington found and shot it. A portion of food was retrieved from the carcass, along with a strange medallion the coyote had in his mouth.

They set up the bait and waited behind a rock.

When the animal approached the meal they tried to shoot it, but the coyote was too fast. It snatched the food, but left behind a strange medallion.
Unfortunately, they didn't have any food.
Giant Cave

The group entered a giant cave, no doubt home to a host of bats, spiders and snakes.

Near the entrance next to a burnt-out fireplace lay a corpse. The man had on official-looking attire and had clearly died of cold and hunger.

Harrington found a note in his inner pocket: "Keecham, I'm worried rebels will attack the bank. Be sure to change the safe code to 3-2-3-2-."
The posse entered the cave carefully, without illuminating their way.
The posse entered the cave with torches to light the way.
They saw gold nuggets shining in the darkness near the entrance.

Illuminating the darkness revealed gold nuggets and a bag marked with strange symbols that contained two bullets.

However, the light seemed to enrage a flock of vampire bats which now swept down on the posse. Everyone escaped, but they were bleeding from the bites and worried they'd contracted some sort of disease.
Whitefog Waterfall

The Undertaker discovered a waterfall. A human skeleton lay at its edge, stuck on a rock.
An old, worn-out purse was still attached to its belt and it held a gun tightly in its dead fingers.
The Undertaker grabbed the weapon.
The Undertaker grabbed the purse.
Unclenching its fingers to loosen the weapon disrupted the skeleton which tumbled into the water, taking the purse with it.
Picking up the heavy purse disrupted the skeleton. Its arm broke loose and disappeared into the water along with the weapon.
Bear with the broken skull!
A giant of a bear with a festering wound on its head charged furiously towards the Undertaker.
Broken skull trophy
Undertaker managed to kill the monster and recover its skull. An old rifle bullet was lodged in the dead animal's eyebrow.
A hut in the swamp

The group arrived at a hut made of rotting planks and moss. Dozens of candles lit the interior in a cozy fashion. The walls were decorated with herbs and jars filled with eerie specimens.

They were greeted by an elderly and attractive dark-skinned woman.

The Seamstress seemed to know why they came. She explained that to help them she needed a lock of hair from someone who died in the massacre.

The Undertaker presented the Old Seamstress with a lock of hair. The witch mixed the hair with herbs while muttering spells in an unknown tongue.

She spent many hours at it before giving up. She said she had never seen a curse this strong. It was as though it came from the Lord of Hell himself. She knew no way of lifting it.

Before the Undertaker could reply, the Seamstress touched his forehead and he fell unconscious. His companions never otld him what happened next, but when he awoke his aging eyesight was rejuvenated and he felt reborn.
Mysterious Moneylender
The Undertaker borrowed money from a mysterious traveler. He would have to repay the debt eventually.
The mysterious moneylender refused to lend any more. He said the Undertaker had enough to survive.

The man standing at the corner gave the Undertaker a small package, but took everything else. He said everyone made mistakes, and this loan would be repaid when the time was right. In a blink of an eye, he disappeared.
He said you had enough.
Fate Trader
The posse encountered a carriage full of strange items, driven by a toothless dwarf. His cart was adorned with the symbol of a snake biting its own tail.
The Undertaker entered the medic's house.
Medic's house

The shabby house was inhabited by the local medic; a dirty, sleepy man who didn't socialize much.

Apparently most people were too poor to afford healing. But he refused to work for free.
Undertaker required healing ([%0])
Harrington required healing ([%0])
Ashmore required healing ([%0])
Fleischer required healing ([%0])
Johnson required healing ([%0])
The medic quickly got to work: cutting, sewing and smearing wounds with medication.
Undertaker decided to carve something in his carpentry workshop.

He imagined the shapes of an eagle, a coyote, a bear and a vulture.

Each of these animals symbolized something different.
The Undertaker carved a figurine of an eagle - the symbol of marksmanship ([%0])
The Undertaker carved a figurine of a coyote - the symbol of speed ([%0])
The Undertaker carved a figurine of a bear - the symbol of endurance ([%0])
The Undertaker carved a figurine of a vulture - the symbol of good eyesight ([%0])
The process took a couple hours. The figurine, though small, had to be carved perfectly.
Traveling salesman

The group met a wandering salesman going by the name of Russ Mantia, though everyone called him "The Russian".

His wares consisted of so many oddities and luxuries it made one wonder about their former owners. And whether they were still alive.
Additional node

^TOWN - sell [%0]%/buy [%1]%
CARAVAN - sell [%2]%/buy [%3]%
OPIUM SMOKING ROOM - sell [%4]%/buy [%5]%
TOBACCO PLANTATION - sell [%6]%/buy [%7]%
GUNSMITH - sell [%8]%/buy [%9]%
SAWMILL - sell [%10]%/buy [%11]%
DISTILLERY - sell [%12]%/buy [%13]%
WANDERING SHOP - sell [%14]%/buy [%15]%
"PROTECTION" SHOP - sell [%16]%/buy [%17]%
